audio_caption: The audio clip begins with dramatic orchestral music. This fades as a male speaker introduces the topic as artificial intelligence, saying "welcome to the people". He explains that the upcoming videos are AI-generated, not filmed or CGI. After this introduction, a low frequency rumble is heard alongside with a very short musical note.

The audio clip begins with someone saying "Roger, huh?" as if in acknowledgement. This is followed by a male speaker introducing "Sora" which will be available to the public later this year. The speaker identifies Sora as the next generative model by Open AI, the company behind Chat GPT, describing how it made its entrance to mainstream masses. The speaker contrasts what Chat GPT did to disrupt writers, coders and other various disciplines, which suggests a tone of announcement.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating that "ChatGPT is a universal professor" and will "hold your hand and teach you basic maths" if necessary, proceeding all the way to "calculus", spoken in a conversational tone. This is immediately followed by the sound of human speech, perhaps overlapping with the previous speaker, indicating a separate conversation or shouting; the language spoken is distinct from that of the first speaker.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing his belief that Sora will surpass ChatGPT, not in importance, but in industry disruption. He emphasizes this belief, noting his daily use of ChatGPT, sometimes more than Google, except for current events, stating "that's about it" and adding "let's be honest."

The audio clip features a single male speaker, delivering information with a slightly conversational but informative tone. He states, "The Internet is predominantly fueled by videos," going on to emphasize this point with statistics and name various platforms like YouTube and TikTok, then mentions "the almighty adult entertainment industry." A faint, ambient sound suggests the presence of a subtle hum or electronic background noise.

The audio clip begins with a snippet of music. A man speaks in an casual and conversational tone, at one point quoting that he enjoys "jerk off at least twice a day". He then continues, talking about stock footage. The man's tone changes to that of a marketer and he references Lamborghini and YouTubers, drone operators, online distributers. He summarizes that Sora will have a feature to upload images for reference. Finally, he asks a question, "You want a chocolate?"

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing that "b-roll footage" for different projects "will never be the same." He then acknowledges live-action videos and raises uncertainty when discussing CGI videos. He notes something is "hitting faster and harder." The clip concludes with a distinct burp sound.

The clip begins with a calm male speaker contemplating the impact of AI on the animation industry, mentioning AI software, a movie title, and suggesting the potential for disruption for artists used to following directions. A contrasting, energetic male voice interjects with the assertion, "If you stay on this corner, you're going in a box." Returning to the first male speaker, he shifts focus, stating that current technology favors creators who want to lead and bring their vision to life.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker energetically discussing "little nutty ideas" and the transformative potential of software like Sora, which he describes as giving people an entire studio "at your whim." He asserts this will "yield the absolute best, the most creative results" for humanity. Another male speaker interrupts with a dismissive "You do that, we donâ€™t give a shit!". Undeterred, the initial speaker continues, explaining that widespread access to powerful tools like text-to-video generators will lead to new documentaries on diverse subjects like "dinosaurs, mammoths, dragons, ancient Egypt, Greek mythology, Atlantis, a Martian civilization that never existed." Finally, he excitedly mentions the real-life possibility of seeing mammoths due to scientists mixing woolly mammoth DNA with that of an elephant.

The clip begins with a speaker discussing animated art styles, mentioning Pixar, anime, and more simplistic styles like South Park. They express interest in abstract visuals with storytelling, where creativity isn't bound by rules or logic, and then mentions the short film, "Day and Night." They highlight ideas that wouldn't work for a full feature film but are suited for a short duration, leaving the audience wanting more. They then briefly interrupt themselves with a mumbled "uh." A background music plays lightly while the speaker's talking. The speaker sounds enthusiastic and conversational.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker excitedly offering another example from Pixar's "Inside Out" movie, specifically the abstract shortcut scene, where the characters transform artistically as they move across a room. The speaker then suggests that this scene inspired "Doctor Strange: The Multiverse of Madness" in the way Dr. Strange traverses different universes with varying laws of physics and art styles, accusing the latter of copying. The speaker, maintaining an excited tone, digresses, mentioning the Real Wild West that is social media.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing how someone might use a tactic without shame, comparing the internet to a "wild child". He lists online platforms and mentions the use of celebrity images to create fake videos. A musical sound effect, reminiscent of a "whoosh" or transition, is heard in the background.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing safety features in new AI models, such as Sora, and predicting they will eventually be "jailbroken" and misused like ChatGPT, particularly for adult content, slander, and fraudulent activity. He expresses concern about images online being used for malicious intent, including how platforms like OnlyFans might be affected when people can generate new videos based on reference footage of any person. He has a cautionary, slightly worried tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, in a conversational tone, speculating about future AI girl groups, mentioning that they will have "complete fandoms" because of their ability to "dance and interact with fans" on various social media platforms. He also notes that they will be able to create music and music videos, giving an example of "K-pop girl groups, but completely AI."

The clip begins with someone promoting the idea of record labels prioritizing the creation and development of artists that don't have to worry about their personal lives, who will belong to the record labels for life. He emphasizes the absence of problems or drama, and the promise of staying young forever. He concludes his message, inviting listeners to like and subscribe before promising to see them next time. Afterward, the clip transitions to a section with music that feels like a slow, romantic R&B style. A female voice is heard singing, "Ooh baby, yes sir, that's my baby now," with a soulful tone.
